newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Bi-polar monetary regime seen likely after EMU.
newsitem.headline: Bi-polar monetary regime seen likely after EMU.

text.p: A bi-polar international monetary system, dominated by a common European currency and the dollar, will emerge once monetary union gets underway, according to the likely conclusions of an EU report due in April.

In its first attempt to assess the international implications of economic and monetary union (EMU), the European Commission is expected in mid-April to put forward a cautionary position on the the single currency's future.
While the common currency, the euro, is seen rivalling the dollar on the world's monetary stage, this will not happen immediately, officials say.

The dollar's dominance across a broad spectrum of markets coupled with initial investor uncertainty over the euro's credibility means the U.S. currency's international role will be eroded only gradually.
"The euro will certainly take on an international dimension but this is likely to be a gradual process," said one senior EU official.
In its review, the Commission is expected to underscore that the dollar is still the primary currency used in international trade and the main vehicle on foreign exchange markets.
With close to 50 percent of world trade priced in dollars, there is little expectation that the euro's appearance will lead to a rapid repricing of traded goods.

Underpinning its influential role, and an important element in the EU's assessment, is the dollar's widespread use in Asia. For example, recent figures show that close to 48 percent of Japanese exports and an eye-catching 75 percent of imports are priced in dollars.

The U.S. currency's strength in this region -- which includes the rapidly expanding financial centres of Singapore and Hong Kong -- and in the emerging economies of Latin and South America, poses a formidable challenge for the euro.
